data.title: Bob Hoskins' Greatest Movie Moments, From Roger Rabbit to Hook
data.meta_description: Actor Bob Hoskins has died at age 71. Here are some of his most memorable performances.
data.text:
Bob Hoskins—the actor known for playing tough guys who deep down had hearts of gold—has died, his publicist said Wednesday. He was 71 years old and although best known for playing gruff detective Eddie Valiant in Who Framed Roger Rabbit, he had a long series of career highlights (and a few lowlights).

His list of "bests" include, of course, Roger Rabbit and his Oscar-nominated turn in Mona Lisa, the 1986 film where he played a taxi driver who forms a relationship with a call girl. He was also fantastic in Hook as the Captain's right-hand Smee, and as English gangster Harold in The Long Good Friday. His not-best, though, is similarly close to our heart: 1993's Super Mario Bros. was a tragically failed attempt to bring the Nintendo franchise to life (Hoskins himself referred to as the biggest disappointment of his career).

Nintendon'ts aside, Hoskins was one of our faves—here are some of his best performances.

Who Framed Roger Rabbit (1998)

Any kid who grew up in the 1980s knows this film; it was inescapable. Although toons Roger and Jessica "I'm not bad, I'm just drawn that way" Rabbit are the stars, it was Hoskins' hardscrabble toon-hating detective Eddie Valiant who brought it home. Any animated character can be made to sing and dance for laughs, but when Hoskins did it—acting against his illustrated co-stars—it was pure brilliance.

Hook (1991)

Steven Spielberg's reimagining of the Peter Pan tale looks a little crazy in retrospect (Julia Roberts as Tinkerbell and Phil Collins as Inspector Good?). But tapping Hoskins to play Hook's sidekick Smee was genius. It's a movie crowded with insane performances, our man made the best of every minute he was on screen, right down to his exclamation that he "had an apostrophe." (As well as his thwarting of Hook's suicide attempt—like we said, it looks a little crazy in retrospect.)

Mermaids (1990)

OK, so this movie is mostly about Cher (her character is named Rachel here, but she's still Cher) and her two daughters played by Winona Ryder and Christina Ricci. But as one of the poor guys thrown into the mix, Hoskins is awesome.

Spice World (1997)

This is just a reminder that the Spice Girls made a movie called Spice World and that Bob Hoskins was in it. As himself. You're welcome.

Super Mario Bros. (1993)

OK, so it's a lowlight. It's the one movie Hoskins really regretted making and served as proof that successful videogame franchises don't necessarily make for successful movies. He went so far as to tell the Guardian, "The worst thing I ever did? Super Mario Brothers. It was a fuckin' nightmare. The whole experience was a nightmare." Despite his disdain, he was beloved by his co-star John Leguizamo (the Luigi to his Mario). "Dear #BobHoskins rest in peace!," Leguizamo tweeted today, "never worked with a more gentle kind and talented actor!"
